Communication, sociality, personhood and personal values
8. Communication, sociality, personhood and personal values

As for the constitution of oneself as a person, Husserl
(Husserliana, vol. XIV, pp. 170 ff) holds that it occurs,
among other things, in connection with communicative or social acts
(“Mitteilungen”, “soziale
Akte”), which are pre-constituted by the mutual drives and
instincts involved in the education of small children who confidently
“imitate” the linguistic behavior of educators
“loving” them like parents (Husserliana, vol.
XIV, 165f). (For additional aspects of the constitution of personhood,
see the last two paragraphs of this section and the literature cited
there. Further elements of Husserl’s view of personal love, esp.
concerning his ethics, are discussed in Melle 2002; Römer 2011;
Kern 2019, sec. 22f; Crespo 2019; Heinämaa 2020.) The relevant
communicative acts are “I-thou acts”, in which the utterer
empathetically ascribes to the addressee the empathetic ascription of
the “intention (Absicht)” to motivate the
addressee, by means of his or her recognition of that very intention
(cf. Husserliana, vol. IV, p. 192), to behave a certain way
(Husserliana, vol. XIV, 166f in the light of
Husserliana, vol. IV, p. 192); where utterer and addressee
simultaneously perceive each other (Husserliana, vol. XIV, p.
167). Thus, these acts are based on “reciprocal empathy”
(Zahavi 2018, p. 746), notably on “iterated, reflexive empathy:
I empathetically ascribe to the Other(s) an
empathetic ascription of an intention to me”
(Beyer 2018, p. 100). In I-thou acts, the “originarily social
I-thou relationship” is constituted, in which ego and alter ego
deliberately and reflexively motivate each other to display certain
practical forms of behavior (Husserliana, vol. XIV, pp.
171f). It is at this stage that the subject constitutes itself as a
person (belonging to the “world of persons”) by gaining
“personal ‘self-consciousness’” of the sort
just described in the course of I-thou acts (Husserliana,
vol. XIV, pp. 171, 175f). This enables the subject to see him- or
herself as subject to acts of self-determination: “If I
agree [Vereinbare ich mich] with an other [...], the other
determines me to determine myself to take on this or that [commitment;
CB]” (Husserliana, vol. XIV, p. 180). (For some other
aspects of the role of communicative acts in Husserl’s analyses of
constitution see, e.g., Zahavi 2003, ch. 3, sec. C–D; Caminada
2019, esp. ch. 6., sec. 2f.; also see Sections 9f below.)

It is by self-determination through “position-taking”, in
the form of “judgement” or “will”, that the
subject constitutes itself as an individual person. (For the
following cf. Beyer 2013, pp. 94, 110f. For a more recent analysis,
also taking into account the new critical edition of Ideas
II, see Jardine 2022. Also see Jacobs 2010, pp. 353–356.)
What distinguishes an individual personal subject from other such
subjects is a “total” personal “style and
habitus”, including “a certain pervasive unitary style in
the way [the subject] decides by judgement and will”
(Husserliana, vol. IV, §61 p. 277; Husserl 1989, p. 290;
also cf. Husserliana, vol. IV, §59, p. 256). This latter
style depends on the subject’s habits to let itself be determined by
value-motives, that is, by emotional valuings
(“Wertnehmungen”; cf. Husserliana, vol.
XXXVII, p. 72) and, sometimes, also by accordingly motivated explicit
value judgements, which concern the subject’s volitional motives,
regarding which the free subject says ‘yes’ or
‘no’. (These valuings, which motivate the subject’s
will, stand to passive emotional affections as full-fledged perceptual
acts stand to their underlying sensual hyle; they can be looked upon
as nonveridical or veridical, and, in the latter case, more or less
adequate perceptions of (instances of) values; cf.
Husserliana, vol. IV, sec. 44, p. 215, sec. 45, pp. 227f;
Husserliana, vol. XXXVII, p. 326.) 

In the former case (the subject says ‘yes’) the respective
motive becomes “a position-taking that issues from [the
subject’s] own ego”, as opposed to a mere stimulus coming from
outside; the subject “annexes” it on his or her “own
accord” (eignet es sich selbsttätig an), i.e. it
internalizes the corresponding value (Husserliana, vol. IV,
§60, p. 269; Husserl 1989, p. 281). This enables the subject to
get to know itself as an individual person, i.e. with regard to its
“personal character-traits” (Husserliana, vol.
XIV, p. 18), notably by learning “how such and such motives
[...] would affect me, how I, as the one that I am, would act
and could act, how I could, and how I could not, judge, value and
will” (Husserliana, vol. IV, §60, p. 265f; Husserl
1989, p. 278). Husserl’s conception of individual personhood
also underlies his ethics (see end of Section 9).
